function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Emphasis on walking as a mode of transportation can contribute to the spread of contagious diseases in densely populated residential areas.","Impact":"Increased risk of disease transmission and outbreak in neighborhoods with high foot traffic and minimal transportation requirements.","Mitigation":"Encouraging alternative modes of transportation to reduce pedestrian congestion, implementing sanitation measures in public spaces, and promoting personal hygiene practices.","Technologies":"Sanitation systems, contactless technology for public transportation, and health monitoring systems.","People":"Residents, pedestrians, and commuters in densely populated residential areas.","Owner":"Urban planners, local government, and public health authorities."},{"Description":"City planning as a dynamic system involves material and nonmaterial inputs and outputs, potentially impacting the spread of contagious diseases within and beyond the city boundaries.","Impact":"Unmanaged flows of people, goods, and information can contribute to the rapid spread of contagious diseases, resulting in widespread outbreaks and regional transmission.","Mitigation":"Implementing surveillance and monitoring systems for population movement, regulating transportation and trade networks, and establishing emergency response protocols.","Technologies":"Surveillance and monitoring technology, supply chain management systems, and communication networks for emergency response.","People":"Residents, travelers, and traders within the city, as well as neighboring regions.","Owner":"City planners, transportation authorities, and regional health organizations."},{"Description":"Historical and contemporary discussions of urban mobility and spatial structure may overlook the potential impact of contagious diseases on population movement and city networks.","Impact":"Lack of consideration for disease transmission dynamics in urban mobility planning can lead to unforeseen outbreaks and contribute to the spread of contagious diseases in urban areas.","Mitigation":"Integrating public health expertise into urban planning, conducting risk assessments for disease transmission, and incorporating disease control measures into city infrastructure design.","Technologies":"Geospatial analysis tools, epidemiological modeling software, and urban planning simulation platforms.","People":"Urban planners, public health professionals, and policymakers involved in city development.","Owner":"City planning departments, public health agencies, and research institutions."}]}
